qas.question: What crop was a primary source of income during the Heian period?
What was the name of the beneficiaries of Heian culture?
Currency gradually disappeared around what year?
What crop became the primary unit of exchange?
What was a short period of peace?
How was Japan strengthened during the Heian period?
What could average people avoid by acessing rice fields?
Who provided to be compitent at ruling the provinces?
Who were paid fees for theiir services?

context: While on one hand the <b4_0>Heian period<b4_0/> was an unusually long period of peace, it can also be argued that the period weakened Japan <b5_0>economically<b5_0/> and led to <b6_0>poverty<b6_0/> for all but a tiny few of its inhabitants. The control of <a0_0>rice<a0_0/> fields provided a key source of income for families such as the Fujiwara and were a fundamental base for their power. The aristocratic beneficiaries of Heian culture, the <a1_0>Ryōmin<a1_0/> (良民 "Good People") numbered about five thousand in a land of perhaps five million. One reason the samurai were able to take power was that <b7_0>the ruling nobility<b7_0/> proved incompetent at managing Japan and its provinces. By the year <a2_0>1000<a2_0/> the government no longer knew how to issue currency and money was gradually disappearing. Instead of a fully realised system of money circulation, <a3_0>rice<a3_0/> was the primary unit of exchange. The lack of a solid medium of economic exchange is implicitly illustrated in novels of the time. For instance, <b8_0>messengers<b8_0/> were rewarded with useful objects, e.g., an old silk kimono, rather than paid a fee.
